. Most of the inhabitants live in agriculture and fishing, but also tourism is growing. It's a nice place to hang out on the beach for a few days or do some snorkeling.
There is a daily boat leaving to

back to Puerto Villamil at 2:00pm. It's a rough and noisy two hour boatride and cost $30 one-way.
Emetebe has irregular flights to Baltra airport or

Most streets lack adequate street signs, but a civic improvement project is changing this, at least in the center of town.  New sidewalks with lava pavers are also being added. The town is small enough to explore in an hour.  Local children are glad to help you find your destination.
For things to see around Puerto Villamil see

value: is excellent.  You might also ask a local panga owner to take you out to "Los Tuneles", or "The Tunnels", a wonderful area of eroded lava islets filled with sea life.

- there's a nice 2,5-3 hours (return trip) hike to the wall of tears. On the way there are lots of things to see; lakes with flamingos and other wildlife, beaches with hundreds of (really big) iguanas, beaches with sea lions, giant turtoises and there are some view points. Take plenty of water, sunscreen and a hat.
- A nice half hour walk from town through mangroves to the breeding center. Some information and lots of giant tortoises (free)
- there is only one diving center on the island which offers dives for 120-140$.

There are no ATMs in Puerto Villamil or banks.  Very few locations accept credit cards, make sure to bring plenty of cash.
Shops in Puerto Villamil sell food, supplies, and souvenirs.
There are several restaurants and bakeries in Puerto Villamil. Most restaurants serve rice, beans and a piece of meat for around 2 dollars.

value: is a wonderful little cafe serving good food on a clean and charming patio adjacent to the town's main square.  La Pepa is one of the most entertaining characters in the Galapagos.

The nightlive is pretty sedate in Puerto Villamil.

value: is a beachfront bar popular with locals and travelers, good to grab a beer and chill out.

in between the village and the harbour is this quiet friendly budget hostel run by the very friendly artist Plaucio Alvarez. There are 3 simple cottages costing $10,- per person set in a nice cactus garden. Rooms have electricity, toilet and hot shower. Use of kitchen facilities. tel: (593) 097 733 083
address=Barrio las Tintoreras cerca de Escuela Cornelio Izquierdo
directions=follow the main street from the port for 5-10 minutes, it's the high green wooden house to the right
content=The two stories house built entirely from wood offers the cheapest rooms on Isabela which are very good-value and a big communal area with a kitchen on the second floor.

is probably the best deal in town. The clean spacious rooms have airco, television, fridge, private bathroom with hot shower and a view on poza salinas, where sometimes flamingos can be seen. It's run by a friendly family who also serve meals. The price is only $20 per person per night.

content=is popular by travelers. It has a restaurant they also organize tours. There's room for 48 guests distributed in singles, doubles, and triples rooms. All rooms have air conditioners, hot water, private bathroom, and TV.  The price is around $30 per person per night plus taxes and include the breakfast.

content=This hotel is located in front of the Flamingos Lagoon in Isabela Island offers double rooms with private bathroom, hot water, air conditioner, comfortable social areas, wireless internet services and Jacuzzi.
alt=formerly La Casita de la Playa
content=On the beach, near town center, air conditioning, picture windows, quiet, family owned, top notch service.
is the first upmarket place in town.
the newest and most upscale hotel in town.
